contentrichtext.text: {{refimproveblp|date=January 2013}} {{ Infobox scientist | name = Johan Håstad | image = <!--(filename only)--> | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|11|19|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = {{flag|Sweden}} | fields = [[Computer science]] | workplaces = [[Royal Institute of Technology]] | alma_mater = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]<br>[[Uppsala University]]<br>[[Stockholm University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Shafrira Goldwasser]] | doctoral_students = [[Viggo Kann]] | known_for = | awards = [[International Mathematical Olympiad|IMO gold medal]] (1977)<br>[[ACM Doctoral Dissertation Award]] (1985)<br>[[Gödel Prize]] (1994, 2011) }} '''Johan Torkel Håstad''' (born 19 November 1960) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Computer science|theoretical computer scientist]] most known for his work on [[computational complexity theory]]. He was the recipient of the [[Gödel Prize]] in 1994 and 2011 and the [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] Doctoral Dissertation Award in 1986, among other prizes. He is a [[professor]] in [[theoretical computer science]] at the [[Royal Institute of Technology]] in [[Stockholm]], Sweden since 1992. He is a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] since 2001. He received his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in [[Mathematics]] at [[Stockholm University]] in 1981, his [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in Mathematics at [[Uppsala University]] in 1984 and his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in Mathematics from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] in 1986.<ref>{{MathGenealogy|id=79819}}</ref><ref>[http://awards.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=4220823&srt=all&aw=146&ao=DOCDISRT Johan Håstad's ACM doctoral dissertation award]</ref> Håstad's thesis and [[Gödel Prize]] (1994) concerned his work on [[lower bound]]s on the size of constant-depth [[Boolean circuits]] for the [[parity function]]. After [[Andrew Yao]] proved that such circuits require exponential size, Håstad proved nearly optimal lower bounds on the necessary size through his [[switching lemma]], which became an important technical tool in [[Boolean function complexity]]. He received the 2011 Gödel Prize for his work on optimal inapproximability results.
